Even a candidate himself may propose the nomination of another candidate for the same election.

prompt: Who can present the nomination paper of a candidate?
response: A nomination paper shall be presented to the returning officer or the authorised assistant returning officer either by the candidate himself in person or by any of his proposers [s 33(1) read with Section 39(2), 1951 Act]. It cannot be presented by any other person, even if authorised in writing by the candidate or the proposer.

prompt: Whether nomination paper can be sent by post or through any other means of communication, like fax or e-mail?
response: No. Nomination cannot be sent by post or through any other means of communication, like fax or e-mail [see Hari Vishnu Kamath Vs Gopal Swarup Pathak 48 ELR 1]

prompt: Whether the notice of withdrawal of candidature can be revoked?
response: No. Once a candidate has given notice of withdrawal of candidature in the prescribed manner, he has no option or discretion thereafter to withdraw or cancel his said notice [s 37(2) read with Section 39(2) of RP Act 1951].

prompt: How many affidavits, a candidate has to file with his nomination papers?
response: Two affidavits one in Form 26 and additional affidavit as per the form prescribed by the Commission vide its Order No. 509/11/2004-JS.I dated 03.02.2016, regarding dues against Government accommodation.

prompt: Whether the nomination paper is valid, if any of the columns of Affidavit (Form-26) is left unfilled?
response: The Honble Supreme Court in its judgment dated 13/9/2013 in WP(C) No. 121 of 2008 (Resurgence India Vs. Election Commission of India and Ors) has held that in the affidavits filed by candidates along with their nomination paper, the candidates are required to fill up all columns therein and no column can be left blank. Therefore, at the time of filing of affidavit, RO has to check whether all columns of the affidavit filed with the nomination paper are filled up. If not, the RO shall give a notice to the candidate to submit a fresh affidavit with all columns duly filled in. The Honble Court has held that if there is no information to be furnished against any item, appropriate remarks such as NIL or Not Applicable etc as may be applicable shall be indicated in such column. They should not leave any column blank. If a candidate fails to fill the blanks even after notice from R.O., the nomination paper will be liable to be rejected by the RO at the time of scrutiny of nomination papers.

prompt: Whether nomination paper of any candidate can be rejected if the information given therein is incorrect?
response: No, giving wrong information in nomination form is not the criterion for rejection of nomination papers. The Returning Officer can reject the nomination papers as per the provisions contained in Section 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

prompt: Then what is the penalty a candidate faces for filing a wrong affidavit?
response: If a candidate files false declaration or conceals information in affidavit in FORM 26, then he is punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both under Section 26 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951. In this case as per the Commissions instruction dated 26.04.2014, the complainant can move before appropriate Court of Law for action under Section 125A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 directly.

prompt: What is the outer time limit for filing the various documents required to be filed in connection with nomination paper?
response: (a) The affidavit in Form 26, the additional affidavit and Forms AA & BB have to be filed latest by 3.00 P.M. on the last date of filing nominations. Revised affidavit may be filed upto the time fixed for scrutiny of nominations, if the candidate has left any column blank in the original affidavit and the Returning Officer has given notice for filing fresh and complete affidavit. (b)    Oath has to be taken after filing nomination paper and before the date fixed for scrutiny. (c)    Certified extract of electoral roll can be filled up to the time of scrutiny.

prompt: Whether Form AA and Form BB can be sent by Fax or photocopy of the same can be submitted?
response: No.

prompt: Whether Form AA and Form BB can be submitted after 3.00 pm on the last date of filing nominations?
response: No.

prompt: How does open ballot system work?
response: Open ballot voting applies in election to Council of States only. Every political party which has its member(s) as MLAs can appoint an authorized agent to verify as to whom its members have voted. The authorized agent will be seated inside the polling station in seats provided by the R.O. In case of MLAs who are members of political parties, after they mark the vote and before inserting the ballot box, are required to show the marked ballot paper to the authorized agent of their party.

prompt: Whether an authorized agent of a party at elections to Council of States can be the authorized agent of another party simultaneously?
response: No. The spirit behind Rule 39AA of the Conduct of Elections Rules 1961 is that MLAs belonging to a political party shall show their ballot papers (after marking their vote) to the authorized agent of that party only and not to the authorized agent of other parties. As such, the same person cannot be appointed as the authorized agent of more than one party.

prompt: What action is required to be taken by Presiding Officer/Returning Officer in election to Council of States, in case an elector belonging to a political party refuse to/does not show his/her marked ballot paper to the authorized agent of his party or shows his/her marked ballot paper to the authorized agent of other political party?
response: In such case the ballot paper issued to the elector shall be taken back by the presiding officer or a polling officer under the direction of the presiding officer and the ballot paper and keep it in a separate envelope after recording on the reverse side of the ballot paper Cancelled-voting procedure violates. Provision in sub-rules (6) to (8) of rule 39A of the Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961, shall apply in such case. In case before taking back such ballot paper the elector dropped the ballot paper into ballot box, at the time of counting such ballot paper, RO should first separate this concerned ballot paper and it shall not be counted.

prompt: Can an independent MLA show his marked ballot paper to the authorized agent of any party?
response: No, Independent MLAs are required to insert the marked ballot paper in the ballot box without showing the marked ballot to any agent.

prompt: Whether an MLA or Minister can be appointed as authorized agents of the party at the election to the Council of States and State Legislative Councils by MLAs?
response: There is no such restriction imposed by the Commission in elections to the Council of States and State Legislative Council by MLAs.

prompt: Whether the  list  of  electors  to  be  maintained  under  section  152 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 can be amended to include the name of newly elected member of state legislative assembly after the date of notification of election to the Council of States or even after the last date of filing of nomination?
response: In case when a member gets elected to the Legislative Assembly at a bye-election, result of which is declared after the date of notification of election to the Council of States or even after the last date of filing nomination, the name of newly elected MLA should be included in the list of members maintained under Section 152 of the RP Act, 1951. Further, he shall then be entitled to vote at the election to the Council of States if the poll is taken after the date of his election as MLA. This instruction is also applicable in the case of elections to Legislative Council by MLAs.

prompt: Whether a person can vote at any election if he is confined in a prison, whether under a sentence of imprisonment or as under trial, or is in the lawful custody of the police?
response: No. The provisions of Section 62(5) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 provides that no person shall vote at any election if he is confined in a prison, whether under a sentence of imprisonment of transportation or otherwise, or is in the lawful custody of the police.

prompt: What is the condition for getting registered in the electoral roll?
response: The applicant should be an Indian citizen, 18 years or more of age with reference to the qualifying date, and an ordinary resident of the area concerned.

prompt: What is the relevant date for determining the age of 18 years?
response: The qualifying date is January 1 of the year in which the electoral roll is prepared.

prompt: When will the ERO process the advance claims received?
response: The ERO processes advance claims received up to the third day after the last date of filing claims.

prompt: What is the relevant date for revision of electoral roll after the Election Laws (Amendment) Act, 2021?
response: The relevant date for the revision of electoral roll after the Election Laws (Amendment) Act, 2021, is January 1 of the year in which the electoral roll is prepared.

prompt: Can a non-citizen of India become a voter in the electoral rolls in India?
response: No, only Indian citizens are eligible to be enrolled as voters in the electoral rolls in India.

prompt: Can a non-resident Indian settled in a foreign land become an elector in the electoral roll in India?
response: Yes, a non-resident Indian settled in a foreign land can become an elector in the electoral roll in India.

prompt: How can one get registered/enrolled in the electoral roll?
response: One can get registered/enrolled in the electoral roll by filling Form 6 online or offline and submitting it to the Electoral Registration Officer (ERO) of the constituency.

prompt: From where can registration forms be obtained?
response: Registration forms can be obtained from the offices of Electoral Registration Officers or Assistant Electoral Registration Officers.

prompt: What documents are required to be enclosed with Form 6?
response: The documents required to be enclosed with Form 6 include proof of age and residence.

prompt: Is it mandatory to provide the Aadhaar details of the applicant in the field provided in the Forms for registration?
response: Providing Aadhaar details is optional, not mandatory.

prompt: I am a student staying at the place of study in a hostel/mess far from my native place. What should I do?
response: Students staying at the place of study in a hostel/mess far from their native place can get enrolled at the place of study.

prompt: A homeless person, who is otherwise eligible for registration as an elector, does not possess documentary proof of ordinary residence. What is the procedure of verification in such a case?
response: In the case of a homeless person without proof of ordinary residence, verification is done through a field inquiry.

prompt: I am a tenant, and my landlord does not want me to get enrolled. How can I get enrolled as a voter?
response: Tenants can get enrolled by providing the required documents and with the landlord's agreement.

prompt: Where can the postal address of the Electoral Registration Officers be obtained from?
response: The postal addresses of Electoral Registration Officers can be obtained from the website of the Chief Electoral Officer of the respective state or union territory.

prompt: If I apply online, do I need to send a physically signed copy of the form with documents to the Electoral Registration Officer's address?
response: If applying online, a physically signed copy of the form with documents need not be sent to the ERO.

prompt: Where can the list of claims and objections be seen?
response: The list of claims and objections can be seen at the offices of Electoral Registration Officers and Assistant Electoral Registration Officers.

prompt: How will an applicant know that his/her name is included in the electoral roll?
response: The inclusion of names in the electoral roll can be checked online on the official website.

prompt: How can corrections be made if there are some mistakes in the entries in the electoral roll pertaining to electors?
response: Corrections to entries in the electoral roll can be made through the prescribed forms like Form 8.

prompt: I have shifted from my residence where I am registered as an elector to some other place. How do I ensure that I am enrolled in my new place of residence?
response: Shifting residents should fill Form 6 for enrollment in the new place of residence and deletion from the old constituency.

prompt: I have shifted my residence recently. I have Electors Photo Identity Card (EPIC) with the old address. Can I get a new EPIC for the present address?
response: Yes, a new EPIC can be obtained with the present address by applying through Form 001.

prompt: My EPIC has some errors. What is the procedure to have a new EPIC with correct particulars?
response: The procedure to get a new EPIC with correct particulars involves filing an application through Form 001.

prompt: I have lost my old EPIC. How can I get a new EPIC?
response: A new EPIC can be obtained by applying through Form 001, providing the required documents.

prompt: Who can object to the inclusion of names in electoral rolls?
response: Any person can object to the inclusion of names in electoral rolls through the prescribed form.

prompt: My neighbor/relative has shifted his residence to a new place, but his name still continues in the electoral roll. In which Form can the application for deletion of his name from the electoral roll be made?
response: The application for deletion of names from the electoral roll can be made in Form 7.

prompt: When can one get registered in the electoral roll? Is enrollment being on throughout the year?
response: Enrollment in the electoral roll is an ongoing process and can be done throughout the year.

prompt: Can one be enrolled at more than one place?
response: No, a person can be enrolled in the electoral roll only at one place.

prompt: If I have a complaint against the order of Electoral Registration Officer, to whom should I make an appeal?
response: Appeals against the order of the Electoral Registration Officer can be made to the District Election Officer.

prompt: Who is an overseas (NRI) elector? Can an NRI settled in a foreign land become an elector of the electoral roll in India?
response: An overseas (NRI) elector is a person who is a citizen of India and has not acquired citizenship of any other country and is otherwise eligible to be registered as a voter and who is absent from his place of ordinary residence in India.

prompt: How can an overseas Indian (NRI) get registered/enrolled in the electoral roll?
response: Overseas Indians (NRIs) can get registered/enrolled in the electoral roll by filling Form 6A.

prompt: What documents are required to be enclosed with Form 6A?
response: The documents required to be enclosed with Form 6A include a photocopy of the passport and visa.

prompt: Where do the entries pertaining to overseas (NRI) elector find a place in the electoral roll?
response: Entries pertaining to overseas (NRI) electors find a place in a separate section at the end of the electoral roll.

prompt: Whether Electoral Registration Officer is to be informed of the change in the current residential address of the overseas (NRI) electors in the country of his/her residence?
response: Yes, the Electoral Registration Officer should be informed of the change in the current residential address of overseas (NRI) electors in the country of their residence.

prompt: Whether Electoral Registration Officer is to be informed when the overseas (NRI) elector returns to India and becomes ordinarily resident in India?
response: Yes, the Electoral Registration Officer should be informed when the overseas (NRI) elector returns to India and becomes ordinarily resident in India.

prompt: How can an overseas (NRI) elector whose name is enrolled in the electoral roll exercise his/her franchise?
response: Overseas (NRI) electors can exercise their franchise in person at the polling station.

prompt: Is an overseas (NRI) elector issued an EPIC?
response: Yes, an overseas (NRI) elector is issued an EPIC.

prompt: Whether the overseas (NRI) elector should surrender EPIC, if already issued to him, in India?
response: Yes, the overseas (NRI) elector should surrender the EPIC if already issued to him in India.

prompt: Who is a service voter?
response: A service voter is a voter having service qualification.

prompt: What are the application Forms in which various categories of service voters have to apply for enrollment as elector?
response: Various categories of service voters apply for enrollment using Forms 2, 2A, 3, and 3A.

prompt: What is the process of enrollment of any service personnel as a service voter?
response: The process of enrollment of service personnel involves filling the appropriate form and submitting it to the Record Officer.

prompt: Is the spouse (wife or husband) or son/daughter of a service voter also enrolled as a service voter?
response: Yes, the spouse (wife or husband) or son/daughter of a service voter can also be enrolled as a service voter.

prompt: Can one be enrolled simultaneously as a service voter at his native place as well as a general voter at the place of posting?
response: No, a person cannot be enrolled simultaneously as a service voter at his native place and as a general voter at the place of posting.

prompt: Who is a Classified Service Voter?
response: A Classified Service Voter is a voter having service qualification and is enrolled in the last part of the electoral roll.

prompt: Who is a proxy? What is the procedure of appointment of a proxy?
response: A 'proxy' is a person appointed by a service voter to cast his vote on his behalf.

prompt: Can a Classified Service Voter be issued postal ballots by the Returning Officer?
response: Yes, a Classified Service Voter can be issued postal ballots by the Returning Officer.

prompt: For what period does a proxy remain valid?
response: A proxy remains valid for the period specified in the appointment or till the service voter revokes the appointment.

prompt: When should the application for the appointment of a proxy be made?
response: The application for the appointment of a proxy should be made at least seven days before the date of poll.

prompt: In which language is the last part of rolls prepared for service voters?
response: The last part of rolls prepared for service voters is in the English language.

prompt: Is a service voter issued Elector Photo Identity Card (EPIC) like ordinary electors?
response: Yes, a service voter is issued an Elector Photo Identity Card (EPIC) like ordinary electors.

prompt: Is a service voter required to apply for the issue of a postal ballot paper?
response: Yes, a service voter is required to apply for the issue of a postal ballot paper.

prompt: What is the relevant date for the revision of electoral rolls for Legislative Council Constituencies?
response: The relevant date for the revision of electoral rolls for Legislative Council Constituencies is January 1 of the year in which the electoral roll is prepared.

prompt: How can one get registered/enrolled in the electoral rolls for Legislative Constituencies?
response: One can get registered/enrolled in the electoral rolls for Legislative Constituencies by filling the relevant form.

prompt: From where can Form 17/18/19 be obtained?
response: Forms 17, 18, and 19 can be obtained from the offices of Electoral Registration Officers or Assistant Electoral Registration Officers.

prompt: What are the conditions for enrolment in Graduates and Teachers Constituencies?
response: The conditions for enrollment in Graduates and Teachers Constituencies include being a graduate or teacher, not being less than 30 years of age, and fulfilling other specified criteria.

prompt: What documents are required to be enclosed with Form 18?
response: The documents required to be enclosed with Form 18 include educational qualification certificates.

prompt: What documents are required to be enclosed with Form 19?
response: The documents required to be enclosed with Form 19 include proof of being a graduate or teacher.
